global_flags.description: This option shows the version number of the xauth executable.
This  option  indicates  that xauth should attempt to break any authority file locks before proceeding.  Use this  option  only to clean up stale locks.
option  specifies  the name of the authority file to use. By default, xauth will use the file specified by the XAUTHORITY environment variable or .Xauthority in the user's  home  direc‐ tory.

This option indicates that xauth should  ignore  any  authority file  locks.   Normally,  xauth will refuse to read or edit any authority files that have been locked by other  programs  (usu‐ ally xdm or another xauth).
This  option indicates that xauth should not attempt to resolve any hostnames, but should simply always print the host  address as stored in the authority file.

This option indicates that xauth should operate quietly and not print  unsolicited  status messages.  This is the default if an xauth command is given on the command line or if  the  standard output is not directed to a terminal.

This  option  indicates that xauth should operate verbosely and print status messages indicating the results of various  opera‐ tions  (e.g.,  how  many  records  have been read in or written out).  This is the default if xauth is  reading  commands  from its  standard  input  and  its standard output is directed to a terminal.

subcommands.name: An
subcommands.description: authorization  entry  for  the  indicated display using the given protocol and key data is added to the authorization file. The data is specified as an even-lengthed string of hexadecimal digits, each pair representing one octet.  The first  digit  of each  pair  gives the most significant 4 bits of the octet, and the second digit of the pair  gives  the  least  significant  4 bits.   For  example,  a  32 character hexkey would represent a 128-bit value.  A protocol name consisting of just a single pe‐ riod is treated as an abbreviation for MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1.

subcommands.name: Authorization
subcommands.description: entries  matching the specified displays are re‐ moved from the authority file.

subcommands.name: The
subcommands.description: timeout  option  specifies how long in seconds this autho‐ rization will be valid.  If the  authorization  remains  unused (no  clients  are  connected with it) for longer than this time period, the server purges the  authorization,  and  future  at‐ tempts  to  connect  using it will fail.  Note that the purging done by the server does not delete the authorization entry from the authorization file.  The default timeout is 60 seconds.

subcommands.name: exit
subcommands.description: If  any  modifications  have  been  made, the authority file is written out (if allowed), and the program  exits.   An  end  of file is treated as an implicit exit command.

subcommands.name: trusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are trusted

subcommands.name: untrusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are untrusted

subcommands.name: info
subcommands.description: Information  describing  the authorization file, whether or not any changes have been made, and from where xauth  commands  are being read is printed on the standard output.

subcommands.name: quit
subcommands.description: The  program  exits, ignoring any modifications.  This may also be accomplished by pressing the interrupt character.

subcommands.name: version
subcommands.description: show version number of xauth ? list available commands
